Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of pure GO, 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanorods. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Raman spectra of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Scheme of the self-assembly process of BVO/rGO core-shell structured composites. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 High resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, O 1s, V 2p and Bi 4f orbitals of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) The total amount and (b) average rate of photocatalytic O2 evolution from AgNO3 aqueous solution under visible light with pure HT-BVO-NRs, 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The relative concentration changes and reaction rate constants of TOC and TN with bare HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Nyquist plots of HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO electrodes measured in 0.1M NaHCO3 aqueous solution at +0.7V (vs. SCE) irradiated by a 350W Xe lamp equipped with a 420nm light cut-off filter from the uncoated side of the FTO glass (back side). The inset shows the equivalent circuit. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Scheme of photogenerated e− transferring features in HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO electrode. Fig. 9 Oxygen vacancies induced self-assembling synthesis of V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell nanorods with enhanced water splitting efficiency and superior sewage purification capability Yangyang Zhang Yiping Guo ⁎ Qi Du Huanan Duan Yujie Chen Hua Li Hezhou Liu ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites School of Materials Science and Engineering Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Graphene sheets fully wrapped core-shell structured nanocomposites are receiving increasingly more attention in photocatalysis owing to their amazing charge carriers transporting characteristics. However, the preparation of this interesting and valuable architecture remains a big challenge. Herein, we successfully prepared high-quality V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell structured composite nanorods using a facile solution-processed method. Positively charged oxygen vacancies on V4+ self-doped BiVO4 nanorods play a key role in rGO wrapping because they can strongly attract and finally anchor COO anions on them, which finally enables the self-assembling formation of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposite. The optimal photocatalytic O2 evolution rate can reach up to 119.5umolh−1 after wrapping rGO, which is 1.36 times higher than that of bare V4+-BiVO4. Significantly, when treating natural waste water from Huangpu River, 2wt.% V4+-BiVO4/rGO is capable of eliminating 92.6% of TOC and 84.6% of TN under visible light irradiation within 8h indicating its huge practical value. The enhanced photoactivities of V4+-BiVO4/rGO are primarily owing to the fact that rGO shell around the composite nanorods can provide a fast channel for photogenerated electrons migrating and subsequently facilitate e−/h+ separation efficiency. This work provides deep insights into the forming mechanism and properties of high-quality V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell structure, and will facilitate the design of other rGO fully wrapped nanocomposites. Keywords BiVO4 Photocatalysis rGO Wrapping Water splitting Waste water purification 1 Introduction Photocatalysis has long been regarded as the most promising way to relieve water/air pollution and energy crisis owing to its ability to produce strong oxidative species that can degrade nocuous organic pollutants and split water using solar energy alone [1]. As one important visible light driven photocatalyst with a bandgap of ∼2.4eV, monoclinic BiVO4 (m-BVO) is receiving more and more attention owing to its non-toxic, cost-effective, stable, versatile and highly efficient nature [2]. We had reported the preparation of [010] oriented V4+ self-doped BVO nanorods (V4+-BVONRs) with diameters ranging from 15–25nm and huge specific surface areas of ∼28m2 g−1 [3]. It was demonstrated that V4+-BVONRs showed outstanding photocatalytic activities in degrading both rhodamine B and phenol. However, there is still much room for elevating the photoactivity of V4+-BVONRs by boosting the charge transporting characteristics, and this idea will be of great importance. Graphene is one miracle two-dimensional nano material with a conductivity of as large as 108 Sm−1, and has been proved to be the best conductor of electrons at room temperature [4,5]. Recently, graphene has received increasingly attention in areas demanding high charge carriers migrating rate, especially in solar cells, Li-ion batteries and photocatalysts [6–8]. The combination of BVO with reduced graphene (rGO) has been a significant strategy to boost overall photocatalytic property. Q. Yu et al. reported the preparation of sheet-like BVO/rGO nanocomposite with enhanced photocatalytic activity [9]. Y. Wang et al. studied the properties and mechanisms of highly efficient spindle-shaped BVO/rGO composite photocatalyst [10]. However, BVO particles in most reported BVO/rGO composites usually distribute on large rGO sheets randomly rather than being genuinely wrapped, so superiorities of rGO on conductivity are not fully utilized [11,12]. Herein, we report a self-assembling synthesis of high-quality V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell structured composite nanorods. Mechanism of the self-assembling process is revealed. Influences of rGO shell on photocatalytic O2 yielding rate and purification efficiency of natural waste water from Huangpu River are carefully investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of V4+-BVONRs and graphene oxide All chemical reagents are of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. V4+-BVONRs was prepared according to our reported one-step hydrothermal method [3]. Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared via modified Hummers method [13]. In a typical procedure, 3.0g flake graphite and 1.5g NaNO3 were sequentially added into a round-bottom flask with 69ml 98% H2SO4 followed by slowly addition of 9.0g KMnO4 under vigorous stirring for 10min in ice-water bath, the temperature of the mixture was maintained below 10°C during this process. The flask was then transferred to a 35°C thermostat water bath and stirred for 4h. Gradually added 138ml H2O and then lifted the temperature to 95°C to allow further reaction for another 20min. Afterwards, 213ml 55°C warm water and 15ml 30% H2O2 were poured into the above system with constant stirring until the black solution converted to bright brown. Brown products were obtained after suction filtration and again dispersed in 3% HCl solution under sonification for 60min to fully exfoliate residual layered GO. The brown solution was centrifuged at 1000rpm to remove bulk GO, and the target products were washed and collected under centrifugation at 10000rpm for 10min. Finally, the brown precipitates were dissolved into a certain volume of deionized (DI) water to form 6mgml−1 GO solution. 2.2 Self-assembling of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanorods 0.25ml GO solution was mixed with 50ml DI H2O and 30ml absolute ethanol under 30min sonification and 1h agitation. 150mg V4+-BVONRs was added into the above mixed solution accompanied by sonification of 1h and stirring of 2h to make sure that V4+-BVONRs could thoroughly contact with GO sheets and core-shell V4+-BVO/GO would be formed after this process. Mild pre-reduction of GO was performed in the presence of 0.1g L-ascorbic acid under continuous stirring for 12h at room temperature. Afterwards, the chemical reducing temperature was raised to 50°C and continued to stir for 6h to increase the reduction level. Then the suspension was transferred to 50ml stainless steel autoclave and kept at 100°C for 12h to finish hydrothermal reduction. The autoclave moved in circles at three velocities alternatively to make rGO wrap around V4+-BVONRs more sufficiently. Precipitation in autoclave was washed with DI H2O and ethanol for several times and collected with centrifugation. 1wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO was finally obtained after drying the dark green hydrothermal products at 100°C followed by calcination at 230°C for 1h to tuning the concentration of V4+ dopant. 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO could also be gained by increasing the volume of GO solution to 0.5ml and 1ml. Fig. S1 shows the photographs of 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO suspension. 2.3 Preparation of V4+-BVO/rGO photoanode V4+-BVO/rGO film electrodes were prepared on F doped tin oxide (FTO) conductive glass using electrophoretic deposition technique. 150mg V4+-BVO/rGO along with 20mg iodine were added into 75ml acetone under sonication for 10min to form a homogeneous suspension. The electrophoretic deposition was carried out employing FTO glasses as both work electrode and counter electrode at a bias of 200V for 1min and the distance between two electrodes was 8cm. After drying at 70°C for 24h, the obtained electrodes were connected with a strip of copper foil on the conductive side and then sealed using insulating epoxy resin to control the exposed area to be 1cm×1cm. 2.4 Characterization and photocatalytic evaluation Photocatalytic O2 evolution property and the ability to purify natural waste water (water from Huangpu River) are carefully studied to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of V4+-BVO/rGO. Influences of rGO shell on photogenerated charge carriers migrating efficiency are also revealed using photoelectrochemical measurement. All these experiments and many other characterizations are detailed in ESI material. 3 Results and discussion The morphology and rGO coating results of all samples were carefully examined by TEM observation, as shown in Fig. 1 . Figure (a) presents the morphology of the as-prepared bare V4+-BVONRs after heat treatment (HT-BVO-NRs) at 230°C, which is in line with the reported results in radius and length, and no contrast change is observed on the edge of these nanorods indicating nothing is coated on them. The microstructures of 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO composite nanorods are compared in Fig. 1(b)–(d), correspondingly. In order to confirm the formation of core-shell structure, partially zoomed-in views of nanorods in all composites with 10nm scale bar are listed as insets. It is clearly found that there exists a layer of shell with higher brightness around grey rod-like core indicating they belong to different phases and core-shell structure is successfully formed [14,15]. The more transparent shell and darker core can be assigned to rGO and V4+-BVONRs, respectively, owing to their diverse penetrability for electrons [16]. In order to provide clearer evidences of the formation of BVO/rGO core-shell structure, more magnified TEM images are compared in Fig. S2. As a consequence, high-quality V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposite was prepared using our room temperature self-assembling method followed by two-step reduction. Besides, the thickness of rGO shell increases along with GO concentration and are estimated to be 3nm, 6nm and 10nm for 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO composite nanorods according to the insets in Fig. 1. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are measured to calculate specific surface area (SBET) and analyze Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution, as shown in Fig. S3. All N2 sorption isotherms can be classified as type IV curve with H3 type hysteresis loop (P/P0 >0.8) resulting from pores produced by the stack of materials [17,18]. BJH pore size distribution curves demonstrate that most pores in samples are less than 5nm and few mesopore appears after the introduction of rGO suggesting a majority of rGO sheets are successfully wrapped on V4+-BVONRs. Based on Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation [19], the SBET values of 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are calculated to be 34.0m2 g−1, 45.1m2 g−1 and 65.2m2 g−1, respectively, much larger than that of bare HT-BVO-NRs. Hence, the formation of rGO shell on V4+-BVONRs is favorable to photocatalytic properties enhancement. The crystal phase of V4+-BVONRs and effect of two-step reduction were examined by XRD analysis. Fig. 2 shows XRD patterns of pure GO, 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanorods. There is only one wide diffraction peak at ∼10.6° which is typically assigned to (001) of GO and no signal of graphite is detected [20,21]. Therefore, graphite was fully transformed into GO sheets during our modified Hummers’ process. The XRD patterns of V4+-BVONRs coated with 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% rGO are almost the same, and all diffraction peaks consist well with pure HT-BVO-NRs, which is identified as monoclinic scheelite phase with a space group of I2/a (JCPDS no. 14-0688) according to the appearance of the small peak at ∼15.1° and peak splitting of (200) and (002) [3,22]. It is noteworthy that the (001) peak of GO completely disappears in all V4+-BVO/rGO nanocomposites implying GO shell has been effectively reduced to rGO by the combination of mild L-ascorbic acid chemical reduction and hydrothermal reduction. Compared with GO, rGO loading is more desirable for photocatalysis because of its higher conductivity, which is beneficial to the separation and migration of photogenerated e−/h+. Therefore, the two-step reduction employed in this work is not only able to convert GO to highly conductive rGO, but also retain the most active monoclinic phase of V4+-BVONRs. Raman spectroscopy was used to judge the reduction and disorder degree of GO owing to its ability to distinguish sp3 from sp2 hybridization [23]. Fig. 3 displays Raman spectra of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. The Raman shifts at 1351 and 1601cm−1 for GO are known as D and G bands which arise from the Raman vibration of sp3 hybridized carbon and conjugated graphene network (sp2 carbon), respectively [24]. After reduction, both D and G bands shift to lower wave numbers which are measured to be 1338 and 1590cm−1. The red shifts, which result from the formation of plenty of defective hexatomic rings during the reconstruction of oxygen-contained functional groups on GO, suggest that GO is effectively reduced [25]. It is well-known that sp3 hybridized carbon atoms mainly exist on edges of graphene domains, hence stronger D band intensity implies higher percentage of boundary carbon and smaller average size of graphene domains [26]. After reduction, the D and G band intensity ratio (ID/IG) of core-shell composite nanorods increases from 1.18 to 1.99, nearly doubled. The enlarged ID/IG value of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO demonstrates that the reduction of GO can lead to an obvious decline on the average dimension of graphene fragments attached on V4+-BVONRs [27]. This phenomenon probably results from the high curvature and internal tension of graphene sheet wrapped on nanoscaled V4+-BVONRs. When a mass of COC groups are destroyed during reduction, the improved energy barrier to form new conjugated hexatomic rings will tear large graphene sheets apart and give rise to massive tiny cracks within the rGO shell [16]. The emerging cracks can provide channels for photogenerated h+ to react with H2O to generate highly active species like OH that is crucial to photocatalytic oxygen evolution and waste water purification. All rest Raman peaks locating at lower wave numbers consist well with pure m-BVO also implying the V4+-BVONRs core is phase pure. The strongest peak at 822cm−1 originates from the symmetric stretching vibration of V-O bonds. The 347cm−1 peak is made up of two parts, the symmetric and asymmetric banding modes of V O 4 3 − at 366cm−1 and 323cm−1 [28]. As a result, high-quality graphene shell with diminished rGO domain size and sufficient h+/H2O channels was obtained on the surface of monoclinic V4+-BVONRs. In most reported rGO loaded composite photocatalysts, semiconductor particles disperse randomly on rGO sheet rather than be tightly wrapped by it, because graphene sheets usually need to overcome high energy barrier to compactly coat on photocatalysts particles [8]. The reason why high-quality V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell architecture is formed should lies on the surface properties of V4+-BVONRs and worth exploring. It has been demonstrated in one of our previous studies that the as-obtained V4+-BVONRs contains abundant positive charged oxygen vacancies ( V O + ) induced by V4+ dopants [3], and this conclusion is also supported by the following XPS analysis in this work. GO sheets are rich in COOH group and will ionized into negative charged COO anion in the suspension of GO and V4+-BVONRs [29]. Both concentration and electronegativity of COO− are larger than other anions (OH and OH) [30], in the precursor, which endows COO− with the highest priority to occupy positions of V O + . As a consequence, COO groups are certain to drive GO sheet to get close to and be anchored on the surface of V4+-BVONRs, as shown in Fig. 4 . From the perspective of V O + , V4+-BVONRs is similar to ZnO which also contains a mass of V O + and has been used to get rGO wrapped composite based on electrostatic force [31–33]. Hence, the strong interaction between COO and V O + plays a key role in the evolution of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell structure. Surface chemical states and bonding characteristics of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are examined by XPS. XPS full survey of these two samples are essentially the same and made up of signals of C, O, V and Bi elements, as shown in Fig. S4. Fig. 5 presents the high resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, O 1s, V 2p and Bi 4f orbitals. The C 1s signals in Fig. 5(a) are contributed by two kinds of materials, one is graphene and the other one is organic impurities with a binding energy of 284.8eV introduced by vacuum system of the instrument, which is commonly used as reference binding energy to eliminate errors caused by charge effect [34]. It is found that C 1s signals of both samples can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which belong to OCO, CO and CC, correspondingly, using Gauss-Lorentz (GL) fitting method[35]. The CC:CO:OCO ratio in 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO is calculated to be 49:42:9, however, the value changes to 74:15:11 after GO is reduced. It can be clearly seen that CO species is largely reduced to CC while the content of OCO barely changes indicating the stability of OCO is obviously strengthened. The improved resistance of OCO against chemical and hydrothermal reduction can be well ascribed to the anchoring effect of COO at V O + positions. The high-resolution O 1s XPS spectra are compared in Fig. 5(b) and can also be deconvoluted into three peaks corresponding to CO, CO and lattice O of V4+-BVONRs (Olatt) [36]. The CO:CO:Olatt ratios are determined to be 52:39:9 and 9:40:51, respectively, before and after reduction of GO shell. In accordance with the analyses of XRD, Raman and C 1s XPS spectra, most COC groups are reduced while OCO species is well retained owing to the anchoring effect of V O + . Interestingly, the concentration of Olatt is relatively low in the initial 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO composite, and this can be attributed to the shielding effect of a plenty of COC after taking the very limited detecting depth of XPS into account [37,38]. After most COC is reduced, the percentage of Olatt increases from 9% to 51% synchronously, which further verifies that nearly all GO sheets are successfully wrapped on V4+-BVONRs, coincides well with TEM observation. Fig. 5(c) and (d) are the high-resolution XPS spectra of V 2p and Bi 4f for two samples, which consist well with our previously reported results [3]. The obviously asymmetric V 2p3/2 peak of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/GO also indicates the existence of V4+ species and the ratio of V5+: V4+ is estimated to be 76:24 using the Gaussian-Lorentzian (GL) fitting method, close to the reported value. Hence, there should be a mass of V O + induced by V4+ distributes on the surface of V4+-BVONRs and propels GO sheets to be fixed on. Similar to our reported result, although the V 2p3/2 peak of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO seems to be symmetric, there should still be many V4+ species as many reported Ti3+ self-doped TiO2 with high concentration of Ti3+ ions also presents a symmetric Ti 2p3/2 peak [39,40]. The binding energies of Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 are ∼159.0eV and ∼164.3eV, respectively, which agree well with the values reported in previous studies [41], as shown in Fig. 5(d). A ∼0.2eV blue shift is observed for Bi 4f peaks after reduction and heat treatment and this is also an evidence of V4+ doping and concentration tuning. As a whole, XPS analysis effectively supports the formation of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell architecture and fully proves that our explanation on the self-assembling process is reasonable. m-BVO has been demonstrated to be one highly efficient photocatalyst for photocatalytic O2 evolution owing to its considerable positive valence band edge position. AgNO3 alone is not photoactive, but has been widely used as an electron acceptor in photocatalytic O2 evolution process for its ability to enhance charge carrier separation and migration [42,43]. In this work, the photocatalytic O2 production efficiency of 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO is studied in the presence of AgNO3 as sacrificial agent, as displayed in Fig. 6 . It is found that the total O2 production within 8h and corresponding evolution rate are 700.9umol and 87.6umolh−1. The O2 yielding capacities are apparently improved after rGO wrapping for all three V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposites, among which 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanorod with an O2 yielding efficiency of 119.5umolh−1, 37% higher than that of bare HT-BVO-NRs, is demonstrated to be the best core-shell photocatalyst. Notably, the photocatalytic O2 production rate slows down when the rGO coating amount reaches up to 4wt.%, but is still superior to HT-BVO-NRs. The overall photocatalytic O2 evolution process of rGO loaded BVO in AgNO3 aqueous solution could be expressed as follows, which is also suitable for V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell composite nanorods [43–45]. (1) BVO+ h v → BVO ( e - + h + ) (2) BVO ( e - + h + ) +rGO → BVO ( h + ) +rGO ( e - ) (3) rGO ( e - ) +Ag + → Ag (4) BVO ( h + ) +H 2 O → BVO+O 2 +H + The above reactions and band positions alignment are further clearly illustrated in Fig. S5, from which one can see that rGO acts as hyperchannel for electron migration and eventually brings about improved photogenerated e−/h+ separation efficiency and elevated photocatalytic activity. The suppressed O2 yielding efficiency in 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO is partially because an excess of rGO around BVO will hinder the light harvesting of BVO and eventually reduce the amount of effective charge carriers and active species, as investigated in Fig. S6. With the increasing of rGO amount, absorbance at wavelengths less than 480nm, the major waveband capable of producing e−/h+ pairs, decreases obviously. The O2 yielding activity of core-shell V4+-BVO/rGO is primarily dominated by photoexcited h+, that’s why AgNO3 is utilized to quench e− to increase the survivability of h+. It can be seen from Reaction (4) that the O2 evolution process involves the reaction of h+ and H2O, which is separated by rGO shell. As has been discussed above, although numerous micro-cracks served as H2O diffusion channels exist within rGO shell, an excessively thick rGO shell inevitably impedes the reaction between holes and H2O. As a result, the obstructed H2O transmission channels along with the inhibited light absorption ability in 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO result in its declined photocatalytic activity in contrast with 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO. One of the ultimate targets for photocatalysts is purification of natural waste water. Therefore, water sample from Huangpu River was used to evaluate the core-shell nanocomposites’ performance in real waste water treatment. The TOC and TN values in the original water sample are measured to be 23.12 and 2.11mgL−1 and the water sample is classified to IV–V polluted water based on national standard GB 3838-2002 issued by Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China. Both HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO can adsorb a small amount of TOC and TN prior to photocatalytic reaction, as shown in Fig. S7. FT-IR spectra (Fig. S8) of bare HT-BVO-NRs and HT-BVO-NRs after adsorption-desorption equilibrium were collected to monitor variation of the amount of adsorbed organic waste, however, no recognizable differences appeared between these two spectra owing to the low concentration of TOC in surface water and poor adsorption ability of photocatalysts. Hence, C/C0 versus time plots that only take photodegradation process into account were used to compare TOC and TN removal efficiencies of all photocatalysts. Fig. 7 shows the removal of TOC and TN without any photocatalyst and with Degussa P25, bare HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO under visible light irradiation in 8h. 25.7% of TOC and 5.2% TN are removed without any photocatalyst owing to the volatilization and direct photolysis of some organics. Excitingly, 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposite is capable of degrading 92.6% of TOC and 84.6% of TN within 8h and is the best photocatalyst. In other words, 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO can convert ∼V waste water to ∼I high-quality water indicating its great potential in treating contaminated surface water. The overall rate constants of photocatalytic reactions (k) could be derived from the regression curves of ln (C0/C) vs irradiation time (t) for TOC and TN decomposition owing to their relatively low concentration, as shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d). The TOC and TN elimination rates with 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are 1.82 and 1.33 times higher than those of bare HT-BVO-NRs and this could be ascribed to the enhanced separation efficiency of e−/h+ pairs. In order to clarify the positive influence of rGO shell on the separation and migration of photogenerated charge carriers, Nyquist plots of HT-BVO-NRs and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are measured and compared in Fig. 8 . It is found that Nyquist plots of two samples can be explained with an equivalent circuit consisting of a solution resistance (Rs), a charge transfer resistance (Rct) in parallel to a constant phase element (CPE), as presented in the inset [22]. Rct is a reflection of charge carriers migrating characteristics inside the photoanode and smaller Rct means higher e− transferring rate. The fitted Rct value of HT-BVO-NRs using ZView is as large as 9843Ω, which is sharply diminished by 83.2% to 1658Ω, close to ohmic contact, for 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO owing to the existence of rGO shell. The photogenerated e− transferring features in two samples are further clearly compared in Fig. 9 . In order to move to FTO substrate, most photoexcited electrons in HT-BVO-NRs have no other choice but trudging through the bulk phase of HT-BVO-NRs and interfaces between them that are of particularly high resistance. Besides, the abundant photogenerated holes within the bulk phase of HT-BVO-NRs have a chance to capture these electrons in transportation. By contrast, in V4+-BVO/rGO anode, photogenerated e− is capable of transporting via interconnected highly conductive rGO shells and avoiding contact with h+ in the bulk phase. As a whole, EIS measurement accurately confirms that elevated charge charier separation and migration efficiency are key factors leading to improved photocatalytic activities. 4 Conclusion High-quality core-shell structured V4+-BVO/rGO nanorods are successfully obtained via a self-assembling process using a two-stage reduction method followed by V4+ content tuning at 230°C. Thicknesses of rGO shell for 1wt.%, 2wt.% and 4wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO are measured to be 3nm, 6nm and 10nm on the basis of magnified TEM observation. It is demonstrated that the strong interaction between positive charged V O + induced by V4+ and COO− anion on GO is the key to self-assembling formation of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposite. After chemical and hydrothermal reduction, GO sheets are well reduced to rGO combined with diminished graphene domain size, resulting in plentiful micro-tunnels that are beneficial to diffusion and reaction of h+/H2O within rGO shell. Notably, being anchored at V O + positions, most COO− groups are well retained in V4+-BVO/rGO to maintain the perfect core-shell architecture. In contrast with bare HT-BVO-NRs, all V4+-BVO/rGO composite nanorods exhibit higher photocatalytic O2 evolution rates and 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO with an O2 yielding efficiency of 119.5 umol h−1 is the optimal photocatalyst. Further more, 2wt.% V4+-BVO/rGO is able to purify contaminated natural water from Huangpu River into qualified water effectively. The enhanced photocatalytic activity in V4+-BVO/rGO is primarily due to the obviously elevated separation and migration efficiency of photogenerated e−/h+ pairs. Instrumental Analysis Center of Shanghai Jiao Tong University is sincerely acknowledged for assisting relevant analyses. coredata.dc:description: Graphene sheets fully wrapped core-shell structured nanocomposites are receiving increasingly more attention in photocatalysis owing to their amazing charge carriers transporting characteristics. However, the preparation of this interesting and valuable architecture remains a big challenge. Herein, we successfully prepared high-quality V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell structured composite nanorods using a facile solution-processed method. Positively charged oxygen vacancies on V4+ self-doped BiVO4 nanorods play a key role in rGO wrapping because they can strongly attract and finally anchor COO anions on them, which finally enables the self-assembling formation of V4+-BVO/rGO core-shell nanocomposite. The optimal photocatalytic O2 evolution rate can reach up to 119.5umolh−1 after wrapping rGO, which is 1.36 times higher than that of bare V4+-BiVO4. Significantly, when treating natural waste water from Huangpu River, 2wt.% V4+-BiVO4/rGO is capable of eliminating 92.6% of TOC and 84.6% of TN under visible light irradiation within 8h indicating its huge practical value. The enhanced photoactivities of V4+-BiVO4/rGO are primarily owing to the fact that rGO shell around the composite nanorods can provide a fast channel for photogenerated electrons migrating and subsequently facilitate e−/h+ separation efficiency. This work provides deep insights into the forming mechanism and properties of high-quality V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell structure, and will facilitate the design of other rGO fully wrapped nanocomposites.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen vacancies induced self-assembling synthesis of V4+-BiVO4/rGO core-shell nanorods with enhanced water splitting efficiency and superior sewage purification capability
